article: I was back at the radiation lab. It was time for my yearly check-up. Sitting there in the office, I _ the cancer treatments, and the first time I had walked into the lab. My legs felt weak. I had looked down the long hallway and could only imagine the _ before me. This was a world I _ expected to enter. I felt _ but fear from what lay ahead. What lay ahead was not as bad as I thought. In fact , the experience brought the unexpected reward of self-discovery. But I didn't know it then. All I knew was that I had been operated _ for cancer and now was to _ five weeks of radiation. My mood showed in my _ . No make-up. No interest in the clothes I had put on that morning. No smile on my face. An attractive woman walked into the building _ I was waiting for my treatment. Stockings, suit, hat, make-up; perfect. "I'm here for my check-up," she said, smiling. I turned to my husband. "You'd never know," I whispered. She had cancer and she looked _ . She had suffered radiation and she was walking, talking, smiling, and _ with the nurse. She was a survivor. I was _ to see her face and to hear her cheerful voice. It made my legs _ when it was my turn to go inside for my treatment. I determined right then and there to someday have her _ . "I'm going to do for someone else what she has done for me," I _ to myself. Now it was one year later. I was _ for a check-up. "How are you doing?" the nurse asked. I had dressed in my special clothes. I had washed my hair and _ applied my make-up. I had been determined to look my best. My new "after cancer" attitude was obvious. "You look great," she said. A man was sitting to my right. His face was pale and _ . His legs were shaking. I knew it was his first time. He looked at me for a long time and I knew what he was thinking. I sent a smile his way. His face brightened and he _ it. I had done my part.
